awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Food Security and Land Use: The Telecoupling Challenge
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 14-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum and the European Joint Programming Initiative on Agriculture, Food Security and Global Change (FACCE-JPI). The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world's major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils.  It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. FACCE-JPI brings together 21 countries committed to building an integrated European Research Area addressing the interconnected challenges of sustainable agriculture, food security and impacts of enviornmental change. Belmont Forum and FACCE-JPI countries participated in this initiative under a funding framework developed by the G8 Heads of Research Councils. This framework supports multilateral research projects that address global challenges in ways that are beyond the capacity of national or bilateral activities. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders.  This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

The Belmont Forum and FACCE-JPI have provided support for research projects that seek to deliver knowledge needed for action to mitigate and adapt to detrimental environmental change and extreme hazardous events that relate to Food Security and Land Use Change.  This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).  

This project brings together researchers and stakeholders from four different countries. The team will use the framework of telecoupling - socioeconomic and environmental interactions among coupled human and natural systems at different scales over great distances - to examine feedbacks between food security and land use. Results of this project include an enhanced capacity to predict effects from shifts in food flows and land use; and tools to facilitate policy changes that will improve food production and distribution while ensuring a more sustainable environment.

por.por_cntn:
The Telecoupling Consortium consists of international collaboration by four countries (Brazil, China, U.K. and U.S.) who have developed an innovative integrative framework,they call Telecoupling that allows examination of socioeconomic and environmental interactions over long distances . Whereas in the past, scientists only tackled how a single coupled human-natural system operated, the use of telecoupling allows the consideration of multiple systems, connected across great distances through international trade. This permits examination of how one system might be sending a commodity such as soybeans (Brazil or the US) to a distant receiving consumer, such as China. In this framework we elxamine not only the production of the commodity in the sending country, but the collateral effects such as the land cover change resulting from the demand for this commodity, and we also examine how the imports of the commondity affect the land cover change and farming in the couontry importing the soybeans: shifts in the crops they grow, what does farm labor do now, and the environmental costs for sending and receiving countries from this trade connection. To do so the project developed sophisticated models, such as FLUTE (Food and Land Use Telecoupling model), that allowed the creation of scenarios such as changes in meat consumption preference, trade wars, business as usual, the impact of a drought in the US, and such. Since 2018 the team has worked and developed a Telecoupling Toolbox and Geoapp, as a way of providing stakeholders with an interactive visualization approach to agricultural data, analysis and data sharing. Together these two tools are designed to engage stakeholders and assist in decision-making. These apps are connected to the FLUTE model and make its use more readily available to all. 

The project developed strong ties to stakeholders in China, Brazil and the US and consulted with them throughout the study period (2015-2021) . We have run workshops on the use of the model and tdhe toolbox across the world, at international meetings such as the International Association of Landscape Ecologists, the Global Land Program, and with Chinese, Brazilian and US farmers' associatdions. In its cuttent form, stakeholders can use their own data to ask questions and simulate outcomes, such as the impact of different crop production costs, the use of different amounts of irrigation and fertilizers, or global commodity prices impacts in a given place. 

Students who participated in the project improved their careers by publication of their research, through international meetings and expanding their network across the world, as many participated in field studies in China and Brazil, and presented their work in Europe, China and Brazil, as well as the U.S. Many of them now are employed by government agencies, NGOs, and academia in China, Europe, Brazil and the US. They learned how to present their work in international venues, how to work with scientists from different discipllines, and how to communicate with stakeholders in the food and agricultural areas.
